text:
If you have a basement,
these crickets
are probably down there.

They’re called spider crickets
or camel crickets,

and they’re an
invasive species.
But boy, can they jump.

You could try to
get rid of them.

Or you could use a
high-speed video camera

to figure out how
these crickets can

leap 50 to 60 times
their body length
and land on their feet.

Researchers at Johns Hopkins
took the second path.

They recruited students who
spent several months coaxing
these crickets to jump.

They found that the
crickets perform

what look like ballet moves
with their legs and antennae.

First, they
streamline themselves.

Then, they angle their
body so that when

they land it will be on
their powerful hind legs,

like a jet landing
on a runway.

Insect movements
can always provide

clues for new
robotic designs.

But what may be a
lot more important,
is looking closely

at a basement pest
and finding beauty.
